title: Why does Christianity put such emphasis on turning the other cheek and loving one's enemies? Is it somehow connected to the persecution of Christians in the Roman Empire, developing as a coping mechanism to combat their suffering? - Quora

response.answer_text: I think the most essential part of any answer to this question is Jesus’ example. “But God demonstrates his own love for us in this: While we were still sinners, Christ died for us.” (Romans 5:8). Since God loved everyone, despite turning their backs on Him and not loving His creation, He died for our sins(imperfections) so we could be reconciled with Him. Christianity is about Jesus, and since He demonstrated a perfect life and gave us reconciliation with the perfect God, we try to follow his example. If God can forgive all of our sins, it really wouldn’t make sense for us to hold it against others when they mistreat us. Of course, we’re still sinful, so we don’t always end up imitating Christ perfectly. It’s easier not to turn the other cheek, so it really doesn’t make sense to think of it as a coping mechanism. I think the most intuitive way to understand the reasoning here is to think of one goal of Christianity in the sense of emulating God as we draw closer to Him, and if God forgives people, we ought to do the same. I hope this helps!
